Translation of 老子 into English.

p.seg: it appears to have been anterior to Ti, the sovereign (? Shang ti, God on High).
Chapter One
The Way that can be told of is not an Unchanging Way;
The names that can be named are not Unchanging Names.
With name, it is the mother of all things.
Therefore, constantly without desire, in order to observe its subtlety;
Constantly with desire, in order to observe its boundary.
These two come forth from the same source but are different in name.
Both are called profound.
Profound and again profound,
The gate of all subtleties.
Chapter Two
When everyone in the world knows beauty as beauty,
then ugliness exists;
When everyone knows good as good,
then not-good exists. Therefore, existence and non-existence produce each other;
Difficult and easy complete each other;
Long and short compare with each other;
High and low incline towards each other;
Sound and voice harmonize with each other;
Front and back follow each other.
Therefore, the sage manages affairs through non-action,
And practices teaching without words.
The myriad things arise, and he does not refuse them.
It produces all things without claiming ownership.
It gives life but does not possess.
It acts but does not rely on its own ability.
It accomplishes its task but does not dwell on it.
Precisely because it does not dwell on it,
it never departs.
Chapter Three
Do not exalt the worthy, so that the people will not contend;
do not value rare treasures, so that the people will not become thieves;
do not display what is desirable, so that the people’s hearts will not be disturbed.
Therefore, the sage governs by:
emptying their minds,
filling their bellies,
weakening their wills,
and strengthening their bones.
Constantly keep the people without knowledge and without desires.
Ensure that those who have knowledge dare not act.
Act by non-action,
and there is nothing that will not be governed.
Chapter Four
The Dao is empty, and in its use it is possibly never full.
How deep it is, like the ancestor of the myriad things!
Blunt its sharpness,
untangle its knots,
Untangle its complexity;
Temper its brightness;
Harmonize with its dust.
Clear and still, it seems to exist;
I do not know whose offspring it is.
Chapter 5
Heaven and Earth are not benevolent;
They regard the myriad things as straw dogs.
The sage is not benevolent;
He regards the people as straw dogs.
The space between Heaven and Earth,
Is it not like a bellows?
Empty, yet it is inexhaustible;
The more it is moved, the more it produces.
Much talk leads to exhaustion;
It is better to hold to the center.
Chapter 6
The spirit of the valley never dies;
It is called the Mysterious Female.
The gate of the Mysterious Female,
Is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
Continuously it seems to exist;
Draw upon it, and it never fails.
Chapter 7
Heaven is long, Earth is enduring.
The reason why Heaven and Earth can be long and enduring
is that they do not live for themselves;
therefore, they can live long.
Therefore, the sage
puts himself last, and yet he is first;
he puts himself outside, and yet he endures.
Is it not because of his selflessness?
Therefore, he can accomplish his self-interest.
Chapter Eight
The highest good is like water.
Water benefits all things
and does not compete.
It dwells in places that people despise.
Therefore, it is close to the Dao.
In dwelling, it is good to be near the ground;
in the heart, it is good to be deep;
in giving, it is good to be kind;
in words, it is good to be trustworthy;
in government, it is good to be orderly;
in affairs, it is good to be capable;
in action, it is good to be timely.
It is precisely because it does not compete
that it is without fault.
Chapter Nine
To hold and fill to overflowing
Better to leave it as it is.
To hammer and sharpen it,
it cannot be preserved for long.
If gold and jade fill the hall,
no one can guard them.
To be arrogant because of wealth and status,
is to bring calamity upon oneself.
To retire when功 is achieved is
the Way of Heaven.
Chapter 10
Can you unite the corporeal soul and the ethereal soul, embracing oneness, without separation?
Can you focus your vital energy until it becomes supple, returning to the state of an infant?
Can you cleanse and purify the deep mirror of your mind until it is without flaw?
In loving the people and governing the state, can you do so without (overbearing) knowledge?
When the gate of Heaven opens and closes, can you play the part of the feminine?
Understanding penetrates in all directions, can you do so without using your wit?
It produces them and nurtures them,
producing them but not possessing them,
acting without relying on (one's own ability),
leading them without dominating them.
This is called profound virtue.
Chapter 11
Thirty spokes
share one hub.
It is because of what is not there
that the carriage has its use.
Chapter 11
Thirty spokes
converge on a single hub.
It is because of what is not there
that the carriage has its use.
Mold clay to make a vessel.
It is because of what is not there
that the vessel has its use.
Cut out doors and windows to make a room.
It is because of what is not there
that the room has its use.
Therefore, having is regarded as profitable,
while not having is regarded as useful.
Chapter 12
The five colors blind the eye,
the five notes deafen the ear,
the five flavors dull the palate.
Racing and hunting
drive people's minds mad;
goods hard to obtain
cause people to act wrongly.
Therefore, the Sage,
in governing, provides for the belly
and not for the eye.
Hence, reject the latter and take the former.
Chapter Thirteen
Favor and disgrace are like alarm,
esteeming great affliction as [one's own] person.
What does it mean that favor and disgrace are like alarm?
Favor, being in an inferior position to obtain it, is like alarm;
losing it is like alarm.
This is what is meant by favor and disgrace being like alarm.
What does it mean to esteem great affliction as [one's own] person?
The reason I have great affliction
is because I have a body.
When I have no body,
what affliction would I have?
Therefore, esteeming the world as [one's own] body,
one is fit to be entrusted with the world.
Cherishing the world as [one's own] body,
one is fit to be entrusted with the world.
Chapter Fourteen
Looking at it, [you] do not see it;
[it is] named "Yi" (even/level/tranquil).
Listening to it, [you] do not hear it;
[it is] named "Xi" (rare/scarce/silent).
Grasping it, [you] do not get it;
[it is] named "Wei" (subtle/minute/hidden).
These three cannot be thoroughly investigated,
therefore they are mingled and made one.
This One,
its upper part is not bright;
Its lower parts are not obscured.
Continuously existing, it cannot be named.
It returns again to the realm of nothingness.
This is called the form of no form,
the image of no thing.
This is called indistinct and vague.
Meeting it, one does not see its head;
following it, one does not see its tail.
Grasp the Way of antiquity,
in order to manage what exists in the present.
To be able to know the origins of antiquity,
this is called the discipline of the Way.
Chapter Fifteen
In ancient times, those who were skilled in practicing the Way were
subtle, mysterious, and penetrating,
so profound as to be unknowable.
Precisely because they were unknowable,
I am forced to describe their appearance:
Cautious, like crossing a river in winter;
Hesitant, as if fearing the surrounding neighbors;
Reserved, like a guest;
Dispersing, like ice about to melt.
Genuine, like uncarved wood;
Vast, like a valley;
Murky, like turbid water.
Who can, in the midst of turbidity, quietly settle and gradually clarify?
Who can, in the midst of rest, quietly stir and gradually come to life?
Those who hold to this Way
do not desire to be full.
It is precisely because they do not desire to be full
that they are able to decline and be newly formed.
Chapter 16
Attain utmost emptiness,
Hold steadfastly to stillness.
The myriad things arise together,
I thereby observe their return.
For things flourish in profusion,
Each returns to its root.
Returning to the root is called stillness;
Stillness is called returning to its destiny.
Returning to destiny is called the constant;
Knowing the constant is called enlightenment.
Not knowing the constant,
Reckless action leads to disaster.
Knowing the constant allows for acceptance,
Acceptance leads to impartiality,
Impartiality leads to kingship,
Kingship leads to Heaven,
Heaven leads to the Way,
The Way leads to permanence.
To the end of one's days, there is no danger.
Chapter 17
The highest [ruler] is known by the people to exist;
Next, they are intimate with him and praise him;
Next, they fear him;
Next, they despise him.
When trust is insufficient,
how can there be disbelief?
How reserved and valuable are his words!
When the work is accomplished and the task is completed,
the people all say, "We did it naturally."
Chapter 18
When the Great Way is abandoned,
only then do we have benevolence and righteousness.
When wisdom emerges,
only then do we have great hypocrisy.
When the six relations are not in harmony,
only then do we have filial piety and kindness.
When the state and the family are in chaos and disorder,
only then do we have loyal ministers.
Chapter 19
Abandon sageliness, discard wisdom,
and the people will benefit a hundredfold;
Abandon benevolence, discard righteousness,
and the people will return to filial piety and kindness;
Abandon skill, discard profit,
and there will be no more thieves and robbers.
These three,
taken as prescriptions, are insufficient.
Therefore, cause them to have something to belong to:
exhibit simplicity and embrace plainness,
lessen selfishness and diminish desires.
Chapter 20
Abandon learning and eliminate worries.
"Yes" and "Ah,"
how much distance is between them?
Good and evil,
how much distance is between them?
What people fear,
one cannot but fear.
How vast and without end!
How vast and without end!
The multitude are merry,
as if enjoying a great sacrificial feast,
as if ascending a terrace in spring.
I alone am still, my intentions not yet revealed,
like an infant before it smiles.
Listless, as if with nowhere to return.
The multitude all have more than enough,
but I alone seem to be lacking.
I have the mind of a fool!
So muddled!
The common people are bright and discerning,
I alone seem to be dull;
the common people are sharp and observant,
I alone am confused.
How still it is, like the sea!
How unrestrained it is, as if with nowhere to stop!
All men have their pursuits,
But I alone am dull, like a rustic.
I alone wish to be different from others,
And value being nourished by the Mother (the Tao).
Chapter 21
The appearance of great virtue
Follows only the Tao.
The Tao as a thing,
Is vague and elusive.
Elusive and vague,
Within it there are images.
Vague and elusive,
Within it there are things.
Deep and dark,
Within it there is essence.
This essence is very real;
Within it there is trustworthiness.
From ancient times until now,
Its name has never ceased,
So that it may observe the beginning of all things.
How do I know the appearance of the beginning of all things?
Through this (the Tao).
Chapter 22
To bend, then one becomes whole;
Bent, then straight;
Hollow, then full;
Worn, then new.
Little, then obtained;
Much, then confused.
Therefore, the Sage embraces the One
and takes it as the model for the world.
Not seeing himself, therefore he is clear.
Not asserting himself, therefore he is distinguished.
Not boasting of himself, therefore he is meritorious.
Not being self-conceited, therefore he is lasting.
Precisely because he does not contend,
therefore no one in the world is able to contend with him.
What the ancients called
"Bent, then whole,"
how could it be empty words?
Truly, be whole and return to it.
Chapter 23
Sparsity of words is natural.
Therefore, a whirlwind does not last a morning,
a sudden rain does not last a day.
Who does this?
Heaven and Earth.
Even Heaven and Earth cannot last long,
how much less can man?
Therefore, those who engage in the Dao,
are the same as the Dao;
Those who embody virtue are united with virtue;
those who embody loss are united with loss.
Those who are united with the Dao, the Dao is also pleased to attain them;
those who are united with virtue, virtue is also pleased to attain them;
those who are united with loss, loss is also pleased to attain them.
When trust is insufficient, how can there be trustworthiness? (How can there not be?)
Chapter 24
He who stands on tiptoe does not stand firm;
he who strides cannot walk (far).
He who considers himself enlightened is not bright;
he who considers himself right is not distinguished;
he who boasts of himself has no merit;
he who prides himself does not last.
From the perspective of the Dao,
these are called “leftover food and superfluous actions.”
Creatures find them repulsive;
therefore, one who possesses the Dao does not abide in them.
Chapter 25
There is a thing confusedly formed,
born before Heaven and Earth.
Silent and void,
standing alone and unchanging,
revolving everywhere and tireless.
It can be considered the mother of all under Heaven.
I do not know its name,
so I style it "Dao";
I am compelled to give it a name, and I call it Great.
Great means ever-flowing,
Ever-flowing means far-reaching,
Far-reaching means returning.
Therefore, the Dao is great,
Heaven is great,
Earth is great,
And the King is also great.
Within the realm there are four greats,
And the King dwells as one of them.
Man follows the Earth,
Earth follows Heaven,
Heaven follows the Dao,
The Dao follows what is natural.
Chapter 26
Heaviness is the root of lightness,
Stillness is the master of agitation.
Therefore, the sage travels all day long,
Without leaving his baggage.
Although there are glorious sights,
He dwells calmly and detached.
Why should the lord of ten thousand chariots
Treat the world lightly?
To be light is to lose the root.
To be agitated is to lose the master.
Chapter 27
The one who walks well leaves no tracks;
the one who speaks well has no flaws to criticize;
the one who calculates well uses no counting devices;
the one who closes well uses no bolts or latches, yet cannot be opened;
the one who binds well uses no ropes or knots, yet cannot be untied.
Therefore, the sage is always good at saving people,
and thus abandons no one.
He is constantly good at saving things,
and thus wastes nothing.
This is called following the light.
Therefore, the good person is the teacher of the bad person;
the bad person is the resource of the good person.
Not valuing one's teacher,
not cherishing one's resource,
although intelligent, is greatly confused.
This is called the essential subtlety.
Chapter Twenty-Eight
Knowing the male,
keep to the female,
and be the ravine of the world.
Being the ravine of the world,
constant virtue will never depart. Constant virtue will never depart,
and you will return to the state of an infant.
Knowing the white,
keep to the black,
and be the model for the world.
Being the model for the world,
Constant virtue does not deviate; constant virtue does not deviate;
It returns to the boundless.
Knowing its glory,
Guarding its humility,
Becoming the valley of the world.
Constant virtue is then sufficient;
Constant virtue is then sufficient;
It returns to simplicity.
When simplicity scatters, it becomes vessels.
When the sage uses it,
It becomes officials and leaders.
Therefore, great regulation
Is uncut.
Chapter 29
Those who would take the world and act upon it,
I see that they will not succeed.
The world is a divine vessel,
It cannot be acted upon.
Those who act upon it will ruin it;
Those who grasp it will lose it.
Therefore, things either go forward or follow,
Either pant or breathe,
Either are strong or weak,
Either are broken or ruined.
Therefore, the sage discards excess,
Discards extravagance,
Discards arrogance.
Chapter 30
One who assists the ruler of men with the Way
does not use arms to strengthen himself in the world,
for such things tend to rebound.
Where troops are stationed,
thorns and brambles grow.
After a great army,
there are sure to be lean years.
One who is skilled acts decisively and stops there;
he does not dare to take strength through force.
He acts decisively but does not boast;
he acts decisively but does not brag;
he acts decisively but does not become arrogant.
He acts decisively when there is no other choice;
this is called acting decisively but not with force.
Things flourish and then grow old.
This is called being contrary to the Way;
what is contrary to the Way ends early.
Chapter 31
Now, weapons are inauspicious instruments.
Things detest them;
therefore, one who possesses the Way does not abide with them.
When the gentleman is at home, he values the left;
when using weapons, he values the right.
Thus, weapons are inauspicious instruments;
they are not the instruments of a gentleman.
When one has no alternative but to resort to it (war),
tranquility and indifference are paramount.
Victory is not beautiful,
and to consider it beautiful
is to delight in killing people.
Now, those who delight in killing people
cannot attain their aspirations in the world.
Therefore, auspicious matters are valued on the left,
and inauspicious matters are valued on the right.
Therefore, the subordinate general is stationed on the left,
and the supreme general is stationed on the right.
This signifies treating it (war) with funeral rites.
When many people are killed,
lament and weep over them with sorrow.
Treat victory in war with funeral rites.
Chapter Thirty-Two
The Dao is eternally nameless.
Though uncarved wood is small,
the world cannot subjugate it.
If lords and kings are able to preserve it,
all things will naturally submit.
Heaven and Earth unite, thereby sending down sweet dew,
the people, without anyone ordering it, are naturally balanced.
When order begins, names arise;
once names exist,
then one should also know to stop.
Knowing when to stop is how to avoid danger.
The way in the world,
is like streams and valleys in relation to rivers and seas.
Chapter 33
Knowing others is wisdom;
knowing oneself is enlightenment.
Overcoming others requires force;
overcoming oneself is strength.
Knowing contentment is wealth;
acting with vigor is having ambition.
Not losing one's place is enduring;
dying without perishing is longevity.
Chapter 34
The Great Way is pervasive;
it can go left and right.
All things rely on it to live,
and it does not refuse them.
It accomplishes its work, but does not claim it.
It clothes and nourishes all things,
yet does not lord over them.
It is constantly without desire,
and can be named as small.
All things return to it,
yet it does not lord over them,
and can be named as great.
It is because the sage never considers himself great,
that he is able to achieve greatness.
Therefore, it can achieve its greatness.
Chapter 35
Hold to the Great Image,
and the world will go to it.
Going to it without harm,
there will be great peace and tranquility.
Music and food,
will cause the passing traveler to stop.
Therefore, the Dao in its expression,
is bland, without flavor.
Look at it, it is insufficient to be seen;
listen to it, it is insufficient to be heard;
use it, it is insufficient to be exhausted.
Chapter 36
If you would contract it,
you must first expand it.
If you would weaken it,
you must first strengthen it.
If you would abolish it,
you must first promote it.
If you would take from it,
you must first give to it.
This is called subtle discernment.
The soft and weak overcomes the hard and strong.
Fish must not be taken from the deep,
the sharp weapons of the state should not be shown to the people.
Chapter 37
The Dao is constantly non-assertive,
yet there is nothing it does not do.
If lords and kings can preserve it,
the myriad things will transform themselves.
If, having transformed, desires arise,
I will鎮(zhèn) them
with the uncarved block of namelessness.
鎮(zhèn) them with the uncarved block of namelessness,
then truly they will be without desires;
being without desires, they will be still.
The world will then settle itself.
Chapter 38
The highest virtue is not conscious of itself as virtue;
therefore it has virtue.
The lower virtue does not lose virtue;
therefore it is without virtue.
The highest virtue acts without acting with a purpose;
the lower virtue acts with a purpose.
The highest benevolence acts
without acting with a purpose;
the highest righteousness acts
with a purpose.
The highest propriety acts
but, finding no response,
it rolls up its sleeves and throws itself at people.
Therefore, one loses the Dao. Having lost the Dao, then comes Virtue;
having lost Virtue, then comes Benevolence;
having lost Benevolence, then comes Righteousness;
having lost Righteousness, then comes Ritual.
Now Ritual
is the thinness of loyalty and trust,
and the beginning of disorder.
So-called "foreknowledge"
is the flower of the Dao,
and the beginning of foolishness.
Therefore, the great person
dwells in the substantial
and does not reside in the superficial;
dwells in the real,
and does not reside in the flowery.
Therefore, abandon that and take this.
Chapter Thirty-Nine
In the past, those who attained the One:
Heaven attained the One and became clear,
Earth attained the One and became tranquil,
Spirit attained the One and became efficacious,
Valley attained the One and became full,
All things attained the One and came to life,
Lords and Kings attained the One and became the standard for the world.
If they were to lose it (the One),
it is said that if Heaven were not clear, it would likely crack;
it is said that if Earth were not tranquil, it would likely split open;
To say that the spirits will not be able to manifest their power is to fear their ceasing to exist;
to say that the valleys will not be able to be filled is to fear their becoming exhausted;
to say that the myriad things will not be able to be produced is to fear their perishing;
to say that the lords and kings will not be able to maintain their noble height is to fear their downfall.
Therefore, nobility takes lowliness as its root;
height takes the base as its foundation.
This is why lords and kings
call themselves "orphans," "widowers," and "unworthy ones."
Is this not taking lowliness as their root?
Is it not?
Therefore, accumulating excessive praise leads to no praise.
Therefore, one should not desire to be ornamented like jade,
but rather be coarse like stone.
Chapter 40:
Reversal is the movement of the Dao;
weakness is the function of the Dao.
The myriad things of the world are born from existence;
existence is born from non-existence.
Chapter 41:
When the superior person hears of the Dao,
they diligently practice it;
when the average person hears of the Dao,
they are half-convinced, half-doubting;
when the inferior person hears of the Dao,
they laugh loudly at it.
If it were not laughed at,
is not sufficient to be considered the Dao.
Therefore, there is a saying:
it says:
"The enlightened Dao appears dim,
advancing in the Dao appears retreating,
the level Dao appears uneven;
supreme virtue appears like a valley,
the greatest purity appears sullied,
vast virtue appears insufficient,
established virtue appears like theft,
genuine substance appears changeable,
the greatest square has no corners,
the greatest vessel is completed late,
the greatest sound is barely audible,
the greatest image has no form,
the Dao is hidden and nameless."
Truly, it is only the Dao that is good at lending and accomplishing.
Chapter Forty-two
The Dao gives birth to One,
One gives birth to Two,
Two gives birth to Three,
Three gives birth to the myriad things.
The myriad things carry Yin
and embrace Yang,
blending their energies to achieve harmony.
What people dislike
is to be orphaned, widowed, or without virtue,
and the princes and dukes consider it a title of merit.
Therefore, things are sometimes diminished and thereby increased;
or increased and thereby diminished.
Therefore, what others teach,
I also teach.
Thus, the violent and overbearing
will not meet a natural death.
I will make this my teaching's foundation.
Chapter 43
The softest thing in the world
dashes against the hardest.
That which has no substance enters where there is no space.
From this I know the benefit of non-action.
The teaching without words,
the benefit of non-action,
few in the world can attain to it.
Chapter 44
Fame or body, which is dearer?
Body or wealth, which is more?
Gain or loss, which is more painful?
Therefore, excessive love
inevitably incurs great expense;
much hoarding
inevitably results in great loss.
Therefore, knowing contentment
avoids disgrace;
Knowing when to stop
avoids danger,
and can lead to longevity.
Chapter 45.
Great accomplishment seems deficient,
but its use is inexhaustible.
Great fullness seems empty,
but its use is without limit.
Great straightness seems crooked,
great skill seems clumsy,
great eloquence seems stuttering.
Agitation overcomes cold,
stillness overcomes heat,
clarity and stillness can be the standard for the world.
Chapter 46.
When the world has the Way,
swift horses are turned back to fertilize the fields;
when the world is without the Way,
warhorses breed in the suburbs.
No crime is greater than being covetous,
no disaster is greater than not knowing contentment,
no fault is greater than desiring to acquire.
Therefore, knowing the sufficiency of sufficiency is always sufficient.
Chapter 47.
Without going out the door,
To know the world,
without peeking through the window,
one can see the Way of Heaven.
The further one goes out,
the less one knows.
Therefore, the sage knows without traveling,
names without seeing,
and accomplishes without doing.
Chapter 48
In pursuing learning, one gains day by day;
in pursuing the Way, one loses day by day.
Lose and again lose,
until one arrives at non-action.
By non-action
nothing is left undone.
Taking the world is always done by not interfering;
if one interferes,
one is not worthy of taking the world.
Chapter 49
The sage has no fixed mind;
he takes the mind of the people as his own.
To those who are good, I am good;
to those who are not good, I am also good;
thus virtue is attained.
To those who are trustworthy, I am trustworthy;
to those who are not trustworthy, I am also trustworthy;
Virtue and Trust.
The sage, dwelling under Heaven,
acts with a receptive mind,
making his heart one with the world.
The people all focus their eyes and ears on him,
and the sage treats them all like infants.
Chapter 50
Going out, one enters death; coming in, one enters life.
Those who pursue life are three in ten;
those who pursue death are three in ten;
and the people, striving for life,
move into the realm of death,
also three in ten.
Why is this so?
Because of the excessiveness with which they seek to live.
It is said that those skilled in nurturing life
walk on land and do not encounter rhinoceros or tigers,
enter the army and are not touched by armor or weapons.
The rhinoceros finds no place to thrust its horn,
the tiger finds no place to put its claws,
the weapon finds no place to insert its blade.
Why is this so?
Because in them, there is no place of death.
Chapter 51
The Dao gives birth to them
and Virtue rears them;
Things take shape,
and circumstances bring them to completion.
Therefore, all things without exception honor the Dao
and value Virtue.
The Dao's honor
and Virtue's value
are not commanded by anyone
but are eternally natural.
Therefore, the Dao gives birth to them,
Virtue nurtures them,
grows them, raises them,
shelters them, matures them,
nourishes them, and protects them.
It gives birth but does not possess,
acts but does not rely,
develops but does not control.
This is called Profound Virtue.
Chapter Fifty-Two
The world has a beginning,
which is considered the mother of the world.
Having obtained the mother,
one can know its children.
Having known its children,
one returns to guarding its mother.
To the end of one's life, one will be without peril.
Block its openings,
close its gates,
To the end of one's life, not diligent.
Open its apertures,
Complete its affairs,
To the end of one's life, without rescue.
Seeing the small is called clear-sightedness;
Guarding the soft is called strength.
Employ its light,
Return to its brightness,
Leaving behind no personal calamity.
This is called practicing constancy.
Chapter 53
Suppose I have a little knowledge,
Walking on the Great Way,
Only deviations are to be feared.
The Great Way is very level,
Yet the people prefer bypaths.
The court is very splendid,
The fields are very overgrown with weeds,
The granaries are very empty.
Wearing patterned silks,
Carrying sharp swords,
Satiated with food and drink,
Possessing a surplus of wealth and goods;
This is called boasting robbery.
Boasting robbery—
Is it not contrary to the Way!
Chapter 54
One who is good at establishing does not uproot;
One who is good at embracing does not let go;
Descendants will continue the sacrifices without ceasing.
Cultivate it in the person,
and its virtue will be genuine;
Cultivate it in the family,
and its virtue will be abundant;
Cultivate it in the village,
and its virtue will be lasting;
Cultivate it in the state,
and its virtue will be rich;
Cultivate it in the world,
and its virtue will be universal.
Therefore, observe the person through the person;
Observe the family through the family;
Observe the village through the village;
Observe the state through the state;
Observe the world through the world.
How do I know the world is like this?
Through this.
Chapter 55
One who deeply embodies virtue
is comparable to a newborn child;
Wasps, scorpions, poisonous snakes will not sting him;
Fierce beasts will not seize him;
Birds of prey will not strike him.
Though the bones are weak and the sinews soft, the grip is firm.
Not yet knowing the union of male and female
yet being whole,
this is the perfection of essence.
Crying all day without becoming hoarse,
this is the perfection of harmony.
To know harmony is to be constant;
to know constancy is to be enlightened.
To increase life is ominous;
to use the heart to command the breath is forceful.
When things become strong, they grow old;
this is called being not in accord with the Dao.
Not being in accord with the Dao, one ends early.
Chapter 56
Those who know do not speak;
those who speak do not know.
Block its openings,
shut its doors,
blunt its sharpness,
untangle its complications,
soften its light,
become one with its dust.
This is called profound identification.
Therefore, it cannot be obtained by intimacy,
nor can it be obtained by estrangement;
it cannot be obtained by benefit,
nor can it be obtained by harm;
It cannot be obtained by prizing it,
nor can it be obtained by despising it.
Therefore, it is prized by all under Heaven.
Chapter 57
Govern a state with correctness,
use surprise tactics in warfare,
and win the world by doing nothing.
How do I know this is so?
By this.
The more taboos and prohibitions there are in the world,
the poorer the people become.
The more sharp weapons the people possess,
the more disordered the state and clan become.
The more cunning skills people have,
the more strange objects arise.
The more laws and ordinances are made clear,
the more thieves and robbers there are.
Therefore, the Sage says:
"I take no action,
and the people transform themselves.
I love tranquility,
and the people correct themselves.
I am not involved in affairs,
and the people enrich themselves.
I have no desires,
and the people return to simplicity."
Chapter 58
When the government is unobtrusive,
the people are genuine.
When the government is meddling,
the people are cunning.
Calamity! It is where fortune leans;
fortune! It is where calamity lurks.
Who knows their ultimate end?
Is there no norm?
Normality reverts to strangeness,
goodness reverts to evil.
The people's bewilderment, indeed, has been long-standing.
Therefore, the sage is square but does not cut,
has edges but does not wound;
is straight but not unrestrained,
is bright but not dazzling.
Chapter 59
In governing people and serving Heaven,
nothing is better than frugality.
Indeed, only through frugality
is it called early submission.
Early submission
is called accumulating virtue abundantly.
Accumulating virtue abundantly
then there is nothing one cannot overcome,
nothing one cannot overcome
then no one knows the limit.
Whose limit cannot be known,
can possess a kingdom.
Having the mother of a kingdom,
can endure for a long time.
This is called the way of deep roots and a firm foundation,
of long life and lasting vision.
Chapter Sixty
Governing a large state is like cooking a small fish;
govern the world with the Dao,
and its ghosts will not be spiritual.
It is not that its ghosts are not spiritual,
but that their spirits do not harm people.
It is not that their spirits do not harm people,
but that the sage also does not harm people.
Because the two do not harm each other,
therefore virtue gathers and returns to them.
Chapter Sixty-One
A large state
is like a lowland stream,
the convergence of the world,
the female of the world.
The female constantly overcomes the male through stillness,
using stillness to be subordinate.
Therefore, if a large state submits to a small state,
it will take the small state.
If a small state submits to a large state,
then takes from the larger state.
Therefore, some lower themselves in order to take,
and some lower themselves and then take.
Therefore, the larger state desires nothing more than to unite and nurture people,
and the smaller state desires nothing more than to be admitted to serve others.
If both get what they desire,
then the larger one should be the one to humble itself.
Chapter 62
The Dao is the mystery of all things,
the treasure of the good person,
and that which the bad person relies on.
Fine words can buy respect,
and fine actions can influence people.
If a person is not good,
why should he be abandoned?
Therefore, even establishing a Son of Heaven,
and establishing the Three Dukes,
even if one offers a large jade disk before a team of four horses,
it is not as good as sitting and advancing this Dao.
Why did the ancients value this Dao?
Doesn't it mean that one obtains what one seeks,
and one is excused from guilt?
Therefore, it is valued by all under Heaven.
Chapter 63
Act without acting,
attend to matters without attending to them,
Savor the flavorless.
Consider the great and the small, the many and the few.
Requite resentment with virtue.
Plan for the difficult while it is still easy;
Do the great while it is still small.
All difficult things in the world
Must arise from what is easy.
All great things in the world
Must arise from what is small.
Therefore, the sage never strives for the great.
Thus, he is able to accomplish greatness.
He who lightly promises will surely have little trustworthiness.
He who sees many things as easy will surely encounter many difficulties.
Therefore, the sage still regards things as difficult.
Thus, in the end, he encounters no difficulties.
Chapter Sixty-Four
What is at peace is easily held;
What has not yet emerged is easily planned for;
What is brittle is easily broken;
What is minute is easily scattered.
Act on things before they exist;
Govern things before they are in disorder.
A tree that fills an embrace
Grows from a tiny sprout.
A nine-story tower
Begins with a pile of earth.
A journey of a thousand miles
A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step.
He who acts defeats his purpose;
he who grasps loses.
Therefore the sage does nothing,
and so defeats nothing;
grasps nothing,
and so loses nothing.
The people, in their undertakings,
constantly fail when they are near to success.
Therefore, be as careful at the end as at the beginning,
and there will be no failures.
Therefore the sage desires what others do not desire,
and does not value goods that are hard to obtain;
learns what others do not learn,
and returns to what the multitude has passed by.
Thus he assists the natural development of all things,
and does not dare to act.
Chapter Sixty-Five
In ancient times, those who excelled in practicing the Way
did not enlighten the people,
but rather made them simple.
The reason the people are difficult to govern
is because they have too much knowledge.
Therefore, to govern a country with knowledge
is to be a robber of the country;
not to govern a country with knowledge
is a blessing to the country.
Constantly knowing these two things,
is also knowing the standard.
Constantly knowing the standard,
this is called profound virtue.
Profound virtue is deep,
far-reaching,
and contrary to things.
Only then does one attain great harmony.
Chapter Sixty-Six
The reason why rivers and seas are able to be the kings of hundreds of valleys
is that they are good at placing themselves below them;
therefore, they are able to be the kings of hundreds of valleys.
Therefore, the sage who desires to be above the people
must put himself below them in his words;
he who desires to lead the people
must place himself behind them in his actions.
Therefore, the sage dwells above
and the people do not feel burdened;
he dwells in front
and the people do not feel harmed.
Therefore, the world gladly supports him
and is never tired of him.
Because he does not contend,
therefore, no one in the world is able to contend with him.
Chapter Sixty-Seven
All the world says that my Tao is great
and resembles unseemliness.
Precisely because it is great, it resembles unseemliness.
If it were seemly,
it would have been small for a long time!
It would be small.
I constantly have three treasures,
which I hold and protect:
the first is compassion,
the second is frugality,
the third is not daring to be the first in the world.
Because of compassion, one can be brave;
because of frugality, one can be generous;
because of not daring to be the first in the world, one can become a leader of all abilities.
Now, abandoning compassion and yet being brave,
abandoning frugality and yet being generous,
abandoning being behind and yet being first,
then one will surely die.
With compassion, one will conquer in battle,
and one will be secure in defense.
Heaven will save him,
protecting him with compassion.
Chapter Sixty-Eight
One who is good at being a soldier is not martial;
one who is good at fighting is not angry;
one who is good at defeating the enemy does not engage them;
one who is good at employing people places himself below them.
This is called the virtue of non-contention;
This is called employing the strength of others.
This is called matching Heaven, the ultimate of ancient times.
Chapter Sixty-Nine
Those skilled in warfare have said:
"I dare not be the host, but rather the guest;
I dare not advance an inch, but retreat a foot."
This is called marching without marching,
thrusting without arms,
seizing without an enemy,
holding without soldiers.
No disaster is greater than underestimating the enemy.
To underestimate the enemy is almost to lose my treasure.
Therefore, when opposing forces meet,
the one with sorrow will prevail.
Chapter Seventy
My words are very easy to understand,
very easy to practice;
yet the world is unable to understand them,
unable to practice them.
Words have a source,
affairs have a lord.
Precisely because they are without knowledge,
they do not understand me.
Those who know me are few,
therefore I am valued.
Therefore, the sage wears coarse cloth but carries jade within.
Chapter 71
To know yet to think you do not know is the highest (attainment);
To not know yet to think you know is a disease.
Only by recognizing this disease as a disease,
Can one avoid being diseased.
The sage is not diseased,
Precisely because he recognizes disease as disease,
Therefore he is not diseased.
Chapter 72
When the people do not fear authority,
Then great authority is about to arrive.
Do not oppress their dwellings,
Do not detest their means of living.
Precisely because you do not detest them,
Therefore you will not be detested.
Therefore the sage knows himself
But does not show himself;
Loves himself but does not value himself.
Hence, he rejects the latter and takes the former.
Chapter 73
He who is brave in daring will be killed;
He who is brave in not daring will live.
Of these two, one is beneficial and one is harmful.
What Heaven dislikes,
Who knows the reason?
Therefore, even the sage finds it difficult.
The Way of Heaven
does not contend, yet excels in overcoming;
does not speak, yet excels in responding;
does not summon, yet comes of itself;
is broad and leisurely, yet excels in planning.
The net of Heaven is vast;
though its meshes are wide, it lets nothing slip through.
Chapter 74
If the people are constantly unafraid of death,
how can you deter them with death?
If you could make the people constantly fear death,
and for those who do strange things,
I could seize and execute them,
then who would dare?
If the people are constantly necessarily afraid of death, then there will always be an executioner to execute.
To execute in place of the executioner
is like wielding the axe in place of a master carpenter.
Whoever wields the axe in place of a master carpenter
rarely escapes injuring his own hand.
Chapter 75
The people are hungry
because those above consume too much in taxes;
therefore they are hungry.
The people are difficult to govern
because those above act with
It is because of this that it is difficult to govern.
The people disregard death,
because they seek too earnestly after a life of abundance.
It is for this reason that they disregard death.
Only those who do not value life above all else,
are wiser than those who prize life.
Chapter 76
When a person is born, they are soft and weak;
when they die, they are stiff and strong.
When the myriad things and plants are born, they are tender and fragile;
when they die, they are withered and dry.
Therefore it is said:
The stiff and strong are followers of death;
the soft and weak are followers of life.
Therefore, a strong army does not prevail,
and a strong tree is felled.
The strong and great occupy the lower position;
the soft and weak occupy the upper position.
Chapter 77
The Way of Heaven, is it not like stretching a bow?
It presses down the high,
and lifts up the low;
it diminishes what is excessive,
and supplements what is insufficient.
Therefore, the Way of Heaven
diminishes what is excessive
and replenish deficiency;
the Way of man is not so,
diminishing deficiency
to augment excess.
Who is able to have excess
to benefit the world?
Only one who possesses the Way.
Therefore, the sage acts without relying on his own ability,
achieves success without dwelling in it.
Is it not because he does not wish to display his virtue?
Chapter Seventy-Eight
Nothing in the world is more yielding and weak than water,
yet in attacking the firm and strong, nothing can surpass it,
because there is nothing with which to replace it.
The weak overcomes the strong,
the yielding overcomes the rigid.
Everyone in the world knows this,
yet no one is able to put it into practice.
Therefore, the sage says:
He who accepts the dirt of the state,
is called the master of the altars of soil and grain;
he who accepts the misfortunes of the state,
is called the king of the world.
Upright words seem paradoxical.
Chapter Seventy-Nine
After reconciling a great resentment,
There must be remaining resentment,
how can this be considered good?
Therefore, the sage holds the left side of the contract
and does not demand fulfillment from others.
Thus, the virtuous man manages the contract;
the unvirtuous man manages the collection of debts.
Now, the Way of Heaven has no favorites,
it always sides with the good man.
Chapter 80
A small state with few people;
let them have tools requiring the labor of ten or a hundred,
but not use them.
Let the people value death
and not move far away.
Though there are boats and carriages,
there is no place to ride them.
Though there are armor and weapons,
there is no place to display them.
Let the people return to knotted cords and use them.
Sweeten their food,
beautify their clothing,
secure their dwellings,
and bring joy to their customs.
Neighboring states look upon each other,
the sounds of chickens and dogs are heard from one to another,
and the people, until they die of old age, do not visit each other.
Chapter 81
Sincere words are not beautiful;
beautiful words are not sincere.
The good are not argumentative;
the argumentative are not good.
The knowledgeable are not broad;
the broad are not knowledgeable.
The Sage does not hoard.
The more he does for others, the more he has;
the more he gives to others, the more he possesses.
Therefore, the Way of Heaven benefits and does not harm;
the Way of the Sage acts and does not contend.
